title: 109_s293
content: SECTION 1. FINDINGS AND PURPOSES. The Congress finds that the University of Alaska is the successor to Federal grants for the Alaska Agricultural College and School of Mines, but did not receive all intended land grants. The University of Alaska did not receive all intended land grants, and the Federal Government now desires to transfer certain lands to the University for development. This transfer is in the national interest for the long-term development of a stable population and a healthy economy. Additionally, certain lands held by the University within Federal conservation units will be returned to Federal ownership. The University of Alaska is granted land by the Federal Government to support education objectives. The purpose is to establish the university as a land grant institution with sufficient holdings for operation and maintenance of a university system in Alaska. The University of Alaska is granted land by the Federal Government to support education objectives, including the maintenance of a university system in Alaska and acquiring lands within Federal parks for furthering educational purposes. The University of Alaska is granted land by the Federal Government to support education objectives, including the maintenance of a university system in Alaska and acquiring lands within Federal parks for furthering educational purposes. SEC. 2. LAND GRANT. The University of Alaska is entitled to select up to 250,000 acres of Federal lands in Alaska for a land grant. The Secretary of the Interior must convey the selected lands to the University. Within 48 months, the University can submit a description of lands for conveyance, with the total not exceeding 275,000 acres at any time. The University of Alaska can select lands not yet conveyed to the State of Alaska or Native Corporations, with their written consent. Selections cannot be made in conservation units or the Tongass National Forest, except in specific areas with second growth timber. Selections are allowed in the National Petroleum Reserve--Alaska, with some restrictions. No selections can be made in certain areas within the National Petroleum Reserve--Alaska, including specific Native villages and conservation areas. Additionally, selections are restricted in the Teshekpuk Lake Special Management Area and areas north of latitude 69 degrees North exceeding 92,000 acres for a two-year period. The Secretary aims to reach an agreement with the University of Alaska and the State of Alaska for revenue sharing within this timeframe. The Secretary aims to reach an agreement with the University of Alaska for revenue sharing from mineral leases within NPRA, limiting the University's selections to areas north of latitude 69 degrees North. The agreement would allow the University to receive up to ten percent of annual revenues or $9 million annually. Within forty-five (45) days of receiving a selection, the Secretary must publish notice in the Federal Register, allowing for a public comment period of up to sixty (60) days. Within six months, the Secretary must accept or reject the selection and notify the University with reasons for rejection if applicable. Rejection may occur if it impacts the Secretary's ability to comply with land entitlement provisions of relevant acts. The Secretary must promptly publish notice of acceptance or rejection of a selection in the Federal Register. Actions taken under this Act are not considered major Federal actions. The University cannot select Federal lands reserved for military purposes without approval. Additional lands can be selected to replace rejected ones. Lands or interests in lands must be segregated and unavailable. (e) Lands or interests in lands shall be segregated and unavailable for selection by the State of Alaska or a Native Corporation and shall not be encumbered by the United States. The University may assess selected lands for resource potential and make a final decision within one year of selection approval. Core drilling and geological exploration are permitted, but exploratory drilling of oil and gas wells is not allowed. The University must decide whether to accept lands or interests in lands, with notification to the Secretary. If accepted, all rights of the United States in the selection transfer to the University. Lakes, rivers, and streams in final selections will be surveyed and conveyed according to the Alaska National Interest Lands Conservation Act. Upon completion of a survey, the Secretary will issue a patent for the lands or interests. The Secretary of Agriculture and other Federal departments/agencies will assist in implementing the Act by taking necessary actions promptly. The University of Alaska must convey certain lands to the Secretary as a condition for receiving a grant. The conveyance will be based on approved selected lands, with the University only required to convey the specified lands. The Secretary will accept quitclaim deeds for these lands. Additionally, the Act provides for judicial review. The University of Alaska can take legal action against the Department of the Interior for violations of the Act or to review agency decisions. The action must be filed in the United States District Court for the District of Alaska within two years of the violation. Additionally, there is a provision for a state matching grant. The University of Alaska has the option to take legal action against the Department of the Interior for violations of the Act or to review agency decisions. There is also a provision for a state matching grant where the University can select up to 250,000 acres of Federal lands in Alaska to be conveyed as a matching grant for any lands received from the State. Grants under this provision must be in parcels of 25,000 acres or greater and are subject to the terms and conditions of the Act.
